intro: Paepalanthus biformis, commonly known as the two-form puya, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its rosette-shaped leaves that form a water-holding structure. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically arranged in a dense inflorescence. Paepalanthus biformis is adapted to arid environments and is often found in rocky or coastal areas. Its unique morphology and ecological adaptations make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
